posts.name: Mukhammad
posts.cooked:
Who can help with PID control in VMX. I worked 2 months but still I do not understand why it doesnt work. I have a lot of questions, so in file multiple their written that motor should drive 1 meter but it doen not, it works 4 seconds, but why we need pid if the motor works with seconds. It is very strange. Please help me, I will send the code.

VMX. Contribute to MatchanovMuxammad/VMX development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
If I understand you correctly, you expected the robot to travel one metre and then stop, but it actually travels for four seconds and then stops.  How far does it actually travel?  What does the encoder distance on the smart dashboard say?

Can you post a video of the robot in auto?  Can you put the encoder distance up as a graph on ShuffleBoard and screenshot it?

At the risk of asking a stupid question, are you sure that you’re successfully deploying your code to the robot?  I’ve seen students get very puzzled about why their code changes have no effect on robot behaviour.  One way to tell that you’re deploying is that the “Robot Code” light on the Driver Station will briefly flash red during deployment before going back to green.

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
Have you verified that your encoder is in phase with your motor?

You may not be hitting your set point because you’re encoder distance is running away from your setpoint.

Setup some smartdashboard prints that periodically show your current distance, your setpoint, what values are being sent to the motor controllers, etc.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
A few more thoughts:

With kP=1 and the measurement in millimetres, you’re going to apply full power whenever the position error exceeds one millimetre.

You appear to be using a Titan Quad motor controller.  I can’t see that on the list of FRC-legal motor controllers in R503. Edit: It’s clear from the video that this robot is not intended for FRC.

Consider putting the motor controller into brake mode (if possible) so that the robot will stop when you cut power.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
In the video, you show an encoder distance of -1088mm, but your target is +1000mm.  This suggests that your motor and encoder are inverted with respect to each other.  This is likely because you invert the encoder (but not the motor) in the DriveTrain constructor.

If the PID Controller is trying to reach +1000mm but positive power moves it backwards (towards negative encoder values), it will never reach the setpoint.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
bovlb:

You appear to be using a Titan Quad motor controller. I can’t see that on the list of FRC -legal motor controllers in R503.

This is likely for WorldSkills or another competition using the VMX-Pi, not FRC .

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: Yes.  That became clear to me after I watched the video.

posts.name: Sean B
posts.cooked: Try printing your encoder values to the dashboard and see if they’re changing the way you’re expecting.

posts.name: Mukhammad
posts.cooked: Thanks teacher that was big lesson for me!

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: No problem.  Never stop asking questions!
